>Can anyone have an out of body experience?
Yes, this is a natural part of being human that has been mostly forgotten.

>Does it have to be difficult and take me months or more to attain this ability?
No, the only barrier is your mind - both conscious and subconscious. If you think it's going to be difficult, it will. Many people can be successful within their first few tries. Fear can hold you back.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33392616
>>33392616
What you're proposing is an enumeration but such an enumeration can't be done - if you start at 0, you will never get to enumerate any other number because there is always a number smaller than it. There is no way such a pairing can be actually done.

In contrast with rational numbers, where you CAN do such a pairing (see picrel., you use one of the pair as the numerator and the other as the denominator and you can see that as this sequence continues, each and every one of the possible ratios will appear) that will give natural numbers to ALL the possible rationals - you can create a program to which you give a ratio and it will find you, in finite time, the natural number it's paired to.
There's infinite indexes for 1 in picrel. but I don't think that's an issue for an enumeration (but if it was, you can just modify the function to return the first one when the index of a ratio equal to 1 is asked).

With real numbers, you can't do this "jumping around" approach to give assign each real number a natural index, there is no way to do a matching.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33392117
Look, I know it sounds silly. I'll give a more exact description of what happens.

My breathing works "automatically" as it normally does while I'm doing any activity. But if I focus on it, or try to do anything to my breath, or just simply try to relax, be still and not think about anything, my throat seizes up noticeably, and my breathing completely stops. Then if I don't "force" through the breath or do something else, my muscles will get tighter and tighter all over my body and I will reach the point where I have to gasp for breath with a feeling of weight over the bottom of my neck and over my sternum.

Aside from this, I've had weird physical symptoms that almost feel like the universe is bullying me and trying to get me to spontaneously die or something... the amount of suffering I've been through has been inhuman and if so were to detail it here, you would not believe it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>33392154
you are experiencing 'air hunger', which is the natural prompt to start breathing again after a natural pause
the broken part is that you're tensing up in response to it and freezing.
>I've had weird physical symptoms that almost feel like the universe is bullying me and trying to get me to spontaneously die or something... the amount of suffering I've been through has been inhuman and if so were to detail it here, you would not believe it.
i'd really rather you didn't, but also i believe you completely. i've been there.
you probably aren't going to believe me in saying this, but it is literally self-inflicted. you are living the meme of the kid with his head pressed onto the ground by a boot, but it's just his arm in the boot. you're 'asleep' in a waking nightmare of your own creation.
you need to learn to 'let go' of your body and let it do its body shit again, instead of clenching all your biology like an anxious fist. pick up progressive muscle relaxation, practice it. your 'living hell' with diminish immensely as you learn to let your inner works just flow again, i guarantee it. fair warning: repressed emotional shit and the dealing with it is almost certainly ahead of you. that ain't fun, but it is necessary. you'll make it.
last point: anxiety/fear has probably made you turn your 'superstition' up to 11. be a little more skeptical towards your own experiences- "is it ACTUALLY that? or is this not what it seems?" at the very least, that will help you avoid adding more layers onto the death-spiral.

>Who Is Franz Bardon?:
Franz Bardon was one of the most important figures in the occult revival of the twentieth century and the author of three influential books: Initiation into Hermetics, The Practice of Magical Evocation, and The Key to the True Kabbalah.

In 1941 he was arrested by the Nazis and after refusing to assist Hitler magically, was imprisoned in a concentration camp and tortured. He escaped his execution when the Allies bombed the camp where he was confined. He returned to his hometown after the war, continuing his occult work and writing the books for which he became well known. While studying, he made his living as a healer using alchemical preparations. Bardon was arrested in 1958 by the Czech government for publishing occult materials, and died in prison on July 10, 1958.

>What Is Hermetics?:
Hermeticism, or Hermetism, is a label used to designate a philosophical system that is primarily based on the purported teachings of Hermes Trismegistus.

We begin with:
Darkness = Chaos, Raw potential
Wizard = Guide figure for our protagonist
Light = Illusory, easily manipulated
Dragon = God of destructive power

Pegasus with the all seeing eye that reads minds
Cards becoming the literal avatars of God entities on this plane, that literally kill you if you disrespect them
Occult secret societies pulling the strings of the world from the shadows
the VR arc illustrating how the Matrix works plus Noah's arc
Calls out the fall of Atlantis, Thelema.
Final Arc Yugi is the avatar of Atem on the 2D board aka the game of life where he battles with Satan (Zorc).

Chan literature as a genre is a complex thing. Below is a video that kinda states a core hermeneutic to understand it. The whole series is worth watching if you are interested in Chan and Zen traditions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2qVYHN5gIM&list=PLOLeFveXa_tgK_mQRbbDJ8MoFZ5ZiY6Fv&index=3

Renunciation is connected to compassion and it is not just done for the sake of renunciation. Below is a short write up on it and how it connects. The short idea is that renunciation is born from wisdom of our own suffering. Compassion is born from that same knowledge but with knowledge that there is no eternal essence or substance that is us. Compassion includes oneself and is not stupid either. Critiquing someone or distancing yourself from a harmful person is an act of compassion fo them and yourself conventionally speaking. You prevent them from acquiring bad karma. Below is a good dharma talk on compassion in relation to our relationships. Below is also a more academic talk on it from a comparative philosopher.

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLaAW1H5vg2nFxRKXkISwBPuz4ExDQlWcZ

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Alan Watts is not actually good repersentation of Buddhism, Hinduism or Daoism for that matter. Most traditions of Buddhism will hold that you should treat the existence of those things as a working hypothesis discovered through practice. It is worth noting the ontology of those things can differ between traditions. So they may be conventionally real but not utlitamtely real and what conventionally refers to can differ. Some traditions like Tendai/Tiantai actually prefer to focus with views like iniansanqian or Japanese ichinensanzen, which means something like: “One Moment of Experience as Three Thousand Worlds” that every realm is present in every other realm and and in some not ontologically existent by themselves. Some strands of Theravada and Tibetan Buddhism may hold that they are realms that exist in this realm but may hold we lack the perception because of our ignorance caused by delusion, hatred and ignorance.

I would recommend reading an academic book on Buddhism, pic related, and maybe practicing one tradition and seeing if it works and helps end your mental and physical suffering. If it does then treat other beliefs as working hypothesis. If you don't want to try that, you can always just practice mindfulness and stuff. If you want something a bit meatier than that but not actual full Buddhism, try S.N. Goenka meditation centers. Below are some materials that can teach you about the traditions of Buddhism and the concepts.

https://tricycle.org/beginners/

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5MO7RkS7MhB8lgo6eXotAmw_TrJ5qANt

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD
